I am a scientist, statistician, ecologist, modeller, and lecturer. I am based in Auckland, New Zealand, on the beautiful Hibiscus Coast.




BSc in Zoology from the University of Canterbury
P.G.Dip.Sci in Ecology from the University of Canterbury
MSc in Statistics with First Class Honours from the University of Auckland
PhD in Statistics from Massey University




I have over 20 years experience as a scientist, having worked at the Department of Conservation (DOC), the National Institute for Water and Atmospheric Research (NIWA), and for over ten years as a Lecturer/Senior Lecturer in Statistics at Massey University Auckland. I have been a Workshop Instructor/Research Associate for PRIMER-e since 2017.

Sea Through Science is a boutique scientific consulting company, specialising in statistical analysis, data science, and education. We do much of our work in the life sciences, particularly marine community ecology and fisheries, but we can work in any field or discipline.
Please feel free to drop us a line if you would like to discuss potential projects or just want to get in touch.

title: Baited Remote Underwater Video
text:
Baited Remote Underwater Video, or BRUV, is considered the standard method for surveying fishes and habitats worldwide. BRUVs have several advantages over many other methods of sampling fish communities, in that is efficient, non-destructive, and less species- and size-selective. The video footage becomes a permanent record of the habitat and biological community.



The BRUV unit comprises a metal frame, two video cameras in special housings, lights, and a long arm with a bait cannister.


The team at Sea Through Science have extensive experience with using underwater video methods across the world, including the Galapagos Islands1,2, New Caledonia, Fiji, Tonga, Rangitāhua/Kermadec Islands, the Poor Knights and Mokohinau Islands, all over the Hauraki Gulf3,4, and Fiordland. Adam co-authored the guide to the BRUV method5 and publications in Nature6 and Science7 as part of the Global FinPrint project.
